Not sure, the quote is from a comment on reddit. But it's an idea that I agree with, for sure.
When bankers say "The regulators will not allow bitcoin" they are saying they are afraid of free markets. They haven't faced one in decades
"Free market capitalism is the key bitcoin property that is threatening to disrupt banks: not sequentially hashed files." as seen on reddit
Yes, it is a tremendous opportunity for learning and experimentation. It's both scary and exciting that it is a $100m experiment
I would hope to see it succeed. A decentralized crowdfunding model would be very powerful. If it doesn't, it will be redone.
Better be prepared for pundit talking points without basis in reality ;-). http://ethereumobituaries.com  anyone? It will happen
Oh, I'm not arguing it will impact ETH's survival. It will only impact the price short-term (could be up or down).
It's not necessarily a rational view to associate the performance of one (DAO) to the other (ETH), but people will.
DAO could end up reflecting very positively on ETH. If it works, it provides proof of viability for a huge use-case
There are plenty of Bitcoiners who are also Ethereum fans (and even DAO investors).
People will assign significance to this experiment, the more so because of its size. That's inevitable.
With theDAO comprising 12% of ETH, its success or failure will be seen as a litmus test for Ethereum, overall. That's high stakes, early on.
I would agree however that the probability of the first DAO construct succeeding (or not imploding) is slim.
@ kyletorpey Even a humility avalanche will provide a useful lesson for future developments of such structures.

Trump, in contrast, crosses clear moral boundaries and seems to embody no coherent political belief system beside rage.
I can disagree with beliefs (e.g. socialism) yet recognize actions as arising from genuine beliefs that I do not share.
